review.title: Solving Weighted Voting Game Design Problems Optimally: Representations, Synthesis, and Enumeration
review.abstract: We study the inverse power index problem for weighted voting games: the problem of finding a weighted voting game in which the power of the players is as close as possible to a certain target distribution. Our goal is to find algorithms that solve this problem exactly. Thereto, we study various subclasses of simple games, and their associated representation methods. We survey algorithms and impossibility results for the synthesis problem, i.e., converting a representation of a simple game into another representation.

sections.text: We contribute to the synthesis problem by showing that it is impossible to calculate in polynomial time the list of ceiling coalitions (also known as shift-maximum losing coalitions) of a game from its list of roof coalitions (also known as shift-minimum winning coalitions), and vice versa. Then, we go further by examining the problem of enumeration of weighted voting games. First, we present a naive algorithm for this that runs in double exponential time. By using our knowledge of the synthesis problem, we improve this naive algorithm, and we obtain an enumeration algorithm that runs in square exponential time (that is, O (2n 2 · p (n)) for a polynomic p). Furthermore, we show that this algorithm runs in output polynomial time, making the enumeration algorithm of the best possible.

sections.text: The paper is divided into seven sections. Section 2 introduces the necessary preliminary knowledge and defines some novel concepts. In particular, it introduces cooperative games, with an emphasis on simple games (since our paper is based exclusively on simple games). We will also explain the concept of a performance index, since much of what motivates the results of this paper has to do with a problem related to performance indices. We will give a definition of one of the most popular performance indices (the Banzhaf index), and we will briefly discuss algorithms for their calculation, as well as the computational complexity of this problem. In Section 3, we will define the main problem of interest that we are trying to solve in this paper: the problem where we get a target performance index, and where we need to find a game that its performance index is as close as possible to the given target performance index. We explain that this specific problem is part of a broader family of problems that we call voting problems.

sections.heading: 2.2 Power indices
sections.text: Power indices are used to measure the amount of influence a player has in a monotonous simple game. Power indices were originally introduced because it was observed that in weighted voting games the weight of a player is not directly proportional to the influence he has in the game. This is easily seen by the following trivial example of weighted voting games: [1000; 997, 1, 1, 1]. Here, each player is weighted in only one index: the grand coalition. All players must be present in that coalition to win, and can therefore be said to have the same influence, despite the fact that there is a huge difference between the weights of the first and the other three players. Many suggestions have been made to answer the question of what constitutes a good definition of power in a voting game. These answers are in the form of power indices, which are mathematical formulations for values that attempt to describe a player's "true" influence in a weighted voting game.

sections.heading: 6.1 Implementation details
sections.text: We have implemented Algorithm 3 along with all the optimization tricks described in Section 5.3. The programming language we use is C.Execution of the algorithm involves solving a large number of linear programs using the GNU Linear Programming Toolkit [46], which is an open source C library. As mentioned in the introduction to this section, our implementation solves the (β, Gwvg, Lweights) PVGD problem, where β is the standardized Banzhaf index. This means that for each weighted election game issued by our enumeration algorithm, we must use a method to calculate the standardized Banzhaf index. The algorithm we use for this is simply the naive brute force approach.

metadata.abstractText: We study the power index voting game design problem for weighted voting games: the problem of finding a weighted voting game in which the power of the players is as close as possible to a certain target distribution. Our goal is to find algorithms that solve this problem exactly. Thereto, we consider various subclasses of simple games, and their associated representation methods. We survey algorithms and impossibility results for the synthesis problem, i.e., converting a representation of a simple game into another representation. We contribute to the synthesis problem by showing that it is impossible to compute in polynomial time the list of ceiling coalitions (also known as shift-maximal losing coalitions) of a game from its list of roof coalitions (also known as shift-minimal winning coalitions), and vice versa. Then, we proceed by studying the problem of enumerating the set of weighted voting games. We present first a naive algorithm for this, running in doubly exponential time. Using our knowledge of the synthesis problem, we then improve on this naive algorithm, and we obtain an enumeration algorithm that runs in quadratic exponential time (that is, O(2 2 · p(n)) for a polynomial p). Moreover, we show that this algorithm runs in output-polynomial time, making it the best possible enumeration algorithm up to a polynomial factor. Finally, we propose an exact anytime algorithm for the power index voting game design problem that runs in exponential time. This algorithm is straightforward and general: it computes the error for each game enumerated, and outputs the game that minimizes this error. By the genericity of our approach, our algorithm can be used to find a weighted voting game that optimizes any exponential time computable function.
